awd_titl_txt: Platform-Supported Pairs of Lewis Acidic Metal Cations to Control and Catalyze Dinitrogen Functionalization
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Chemical Synthesis (SYN) Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Polly Arnold of the University of California–Berkeley, is studying the structure, bonding, and reactivity of f-block molecules with the long-term, ambitious goal of converting atmospheric nitrogen to ammonia and amines. Nitrogen gas (N2) is the major component of the atmosphere and potentially an inexpensive, chemically benign starting material for the industrial preparation of a vast variety of important chemical products. Currently, it is the feedstock for a single commercialized reaction, the Haber-Bosch process, which converts nitrogen to ammonia. This process is used on an enormous scale and provides the major source of nitrogen fertilizer worldwide. However, it functions at high temperatures and pressures, both consuming much energy and generating roughly 1% of global annual carbon dioxide emissions. Consequently, the discovery of more efficient processes to convert nitrogen to useful projects is extremely important. This project seeks to develop rare earth compounds that will mediate the conversion of nitrogen into ammonia and related compounds at low temperatures and pressures without generating carbon dioxide. The fundamental research proposed herein is expected to make fundamental contributions to important, unanswered questions about the chemical bonding in compounds composed of some of the heaviest atoms in the periodic table. It will also train members of the future workforce in the chemistry of the technology-critical rare earth elements, and in sustainable catalysis, both of which are high priority science areas for the nation.

Under this award, the Arnold team will develop bimetallic rare earth and related Lewis acidic metal complexes supported by rigid tetraphenolate ligands with important and challenging goal of arriving at entries into the first catalytic conversion of dinitrogen N2 to secondary silylamines by a non-radioactive complex. The proposed program will work with specific lanthanides and co-reductants, according to their size, redox potentials, and Lewis acidity, to define the role of d- and f-orbitals in the stabilization of reduced intermediates and to enable the synthesis of new functionalized amines. Because electrons can be stored and transported through the ligand framework, the proposed program is also designed to tease apart metal/ligand contributions and develop new, lower-energy ways to deliver the reducing equivalents to the N2. The project will train students is the handling and manipulation of sensitive rare earth compounds and in the development of these into reagents for the reduction of small molecules.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Worldwide, the industrial catalytic conversion of N2 to millions of tons of ammonia annually is a starting point for pharmaceuticals, plastics, fine chemicals, and fertilizer, supporting around 3 billion people and addressing the UN global sustainable development goal #2: zero hunger. Biological dinitrogen fixation, 90 % of natural N fixation, is carried out by multi-component metalloenzymes, which have proven resistant to mimicry by simple inorganic catalysts.

Dinitrogen is unusual in that there is only one industrially commercialized catalytic conversion for which it is a feedstock: The high pressure/temperature Haber Bosch process that converts N2 and H2 to NH3, known as the nitrogen reduction reaction (N2RR) is perfectly optimized but still very energy intensive, and can only yield NH3. Small scale, low-energy distributed (global or interplanetary) small scale conversions of N2, including to products other than NH3, and which are compatible with renewable sources of electrons and electrophile, are needed. Meanwhile, ammonia is recognized as a potential major energy carrier to replace fossil fuels, as it is energy dense and compatible with current infrastructures and fuel cell technologies. However, its incorporation into renewable technologies demands further understanding and better catalysts for the redox reactions.

Chemists have spent over a hundred years trying to make ambient temperature/pressure catalytic systems that could convert atmospheric dinitrogen to ammonia or directly to amines. Many complexes of the d-block metals can bind the abundant dinitrogen molecule, but the conversion to products is very difficult, and only a handful of successful d-block metal catalysts have been developed in recent years. Given that many lanthanides are as earth-abundant as 3d-base metals being developed as catalysts (e.g. Ni), and lanthanide chlorides are less toxic than iron chloride, the development of catalysts from these is an equally desirable goal. Further, the knowledge gained addresses the essential need for a better understanding of the electronic structure and bonding in this poorly understood area of the periodic table.  We recently reported simple molecular UIV and ThIV complexes that can convert N2 to ammonia at rtp; structural control by the ligand enables the first catalytic conversion of dinitrogen into a secondary silylamine by any metal. We have now used the same organic ligands support two metals in a more flexible, open platform, forming bimetallic complexes all bind and mediate the reduction of dinitrogen. Some of the f-block complexes show catalytic turnover for nitrogen reduction, others do not. As discussed in the original proposal, we have determined the reasons for the differential reactivity, and in doing so, developed significant new knowledge about the technologically important rare earth elements and their use of d and f orbitals in bonding.

Our reports of the first lanthanide complexes to convert N2 to amines attracted significant press interest and have led to invitations to all the researchers on the project to speak at major international conferences. The isolation of molecules with new, unusual f-electron structures has generated opportunities for new collaborations with spectroscopists and physicists also interested in the f-element challenge. The presentations have also generated dialogue with new startup companies working towards new lower energy routes to nitrogen products.

 

The postdoc presented his research in a talk at the Fall 2023 ACS Meeting in San Francisco, CA, and both the postdoc and PI spoke (the PI was invited) in the dinitrogen session at the 45th International Conference on Coordination Chemistry (ICCC 2024) in Fort Collins, CO. The PI gave a plenary lecture at the ICCC 2023 in Australia and the 2023 Spanish meeting on Organometallic Chemistry, as well as other invited conference talks and seven university colloquia, four of which were named lectures.

 

The project has also helped demonstrate that diverse teams are best able to solve the most complicated problems, and the PI’s internationally recognized diversity in STEM work has been threaded into all aspects of dissemination. At all the university colloquia, the PI held additional meetings with minority student groups to discuss careers and diversity in STEM. One of her lectures at the ACS was the ‘Eminent Scientist Award’ lecture, at which she spent an hour post-lecture in a Q+A session and in one-on-one discussions with undergraduates, encouraging them to stay in STEM and providing tips on grad school applications. The PI also lectured at the Nuclear Summer School at San Jose State University, where she spent all day mentoring the students and discussing grad school opportunities.

In summary, this program has developed new rare earth complexes with unprecedented nitrogen reactivity, and trained future leaders in the chemistry of the critical elements and in the techniques and relevance of sustainable catalysis, both of which are essential to the Nation.
